sections.title: Meet Max, Harvey and Rosie
sections.text: Max is full of ideas. Harvey loves facts. Rosie encourages everyone. Today they are starting a tiny garden of microgreens at home. Microgreens are baby plants you harvest young for fresh flavour and nutrients.

sections.title: What are microgreens?
sections.text: Microgreens are seeds grown for 7 to 14 days until the first small leaves appear. You snip them above the soil and enjoy them fresh. They are simple to grow indoors on a bright windowsill.

sections.title: What is in the kit?
sections.text: 2 half coconut shell planters. 10 coco coir pellets. 3 seed tins that you choose from the microgreens list. 1 wooden spoon for seeds and for spreading coir. Explorer guide. Bee friendly paper. Quest and certificate.

sections.title: Safety first
sections.text: Wash hands and tools. An adult should help with water and scissors. Keep the growing area tidy and dry around the shells. Check seed families for possible allergies. Brassicas. Sunflower. Pea and other legumes. Alliums.

sections.title: Prepare the coco coir
sections.text: Place pellets in a clean bowl. Add water a little at a time until they fluff up. Use the wooden spoon to spread coir evenly in your coconut shell. Aim for one to two centimetres deep. The coir should be damp. Not soggy.

sections.title: Sowing your seeds
sections.text: Sprinkle seeds in a single even layer. No big piles. Press them gently so they touch the coir. Mist lightly so all seeds are damp. Label your shells so you remember what is what.

sections.title: Dark stage
sections.text: Cover the shell loosely with a clean plate or card. This cosy time helps roots grab hold. Peek daily. Mist if the surface looks dry. Keep it slightly damp for two to three days.

sections.title: Into the light
sections.text: When you see sprouts pushing up, remove the cover and give bright indirect light. A sunny windowsill works. Avoid strong midday sun. Mist to keep the coir damp. Not wet.

sections.title: Watering basics
sections.text: Mist once or twice a day. Warm rooms may need more. If leaves droop or coir feels dry, add a few extra mists. If it looks soggy or smells off, ease up and let it air.

sections.title: Roots or mould
sections.text: Root hairs look like tiny white fuzz along stems. This is normal. Fuzzy patches that spread across the surface and smell unpleasant may be mould. Improve airflow. Avoid over watering. Clean tools.

sections.title: Leggy shoots
sections.text: If stems are long and bendy with small leaves, they need more light. Move to a brighter spot with indirect light. Rotate the shell daily so shoots grow upright.

sections.title: Too wet or smelly
sections.text: If the surface looks shiny or there is a musty smell, you have over misted. Give the shell a day with fewer sprays and better airflow. Harvest what looks fresh. Start a new tray if needed.

sections.title: When to harvest
sections.text: Most microgreens are ready 7 to 14 days after sowing. Look for the first pair of true leaves and sturdy stems. Use clean scissors to snip just above the coir.

sections.title: After cutting
sections.text: Rinse gently in cold water. Pat dry with a clean towel. Enjoy fresh for the best taste and crunch. Store leftovers in a lidded container lined with a dry kitchen towel.

sections.title: Easy ways to eat microgreens
sections.text: Sprinkle on cheese sandwiches, omelettes, baked potatoes, soups and salads. Add them at the end so they stay crisp. Try a small handful on toast with hummus or cream cheese.

sections.title: Nutrition. Broccoli microgreens
sections.text: Broccoli microgreens provide vitamin C, vitamin K, vitamin A and folate. They also contain sulforaphane. Vitamin C contributes to normal immune function and to protection of cells from oxidative stress. Vitamin K contributes to normal blood clotting and to maintenance of normal bones.

sections.title: Nutrition. Kale microgreens
sections.text: Kale microgreens are rich in vitamin K and vitamin A, with vitamin C too. Vitamin K contributes to normal blood clotting and to bone maintenance. Vitamin A contributes to normal vision and to normal skin.

sections.title: Nutrition. Red cabbage microgreens
sections.text: Red cabbage microgreens provide vitamin C and colourful plant pigments called anthocyanins. Vitamin C contributes to normal immune function and to protection of cells from oxidative stress.

sections.title: Nutrition. Radish microgreens
sections.text: Radish microgreens have vitamin C and peppery glucosinolates. Vitamin C contributes to normal immune function and to reduction of tiredness and fatigue.

sections.title: Nutrition. Pea shoots
sections.text: Pea shoots provide vitamin K, vitamin C and folate. Vitamin K contributes to normal blood clotting and to bone maintenance. Folate contributes to normal psychological function and to reduction of tiredness and fatigue.

sections.title: Nutrition. Sunflower shoots
sections.text: Sunflower shoots provide vitamin E and plant protein. Vitamin E contributes to the protection of cells from oxidative stress.

sections.title: Nutrition. Rocket
sections.text: Rocket microgreens are peppery and contain vitamin K and natural nitrates. Vitamin K contributes to normal blood clotting. Nitrates can support normal blood flow during exercise by nitric oxide pathways.

sections.title: Nutrition. Spring onion microgreens
sections.text: Spring onion microgreens bring bright flavour and contain plant compounds such as quercetin. Use as a garnish on savoury dishes. This is a general educational note only.

sections.title: Allergens
sections.text: Check seed families and family sensitivities. Brassicas include broccoli, kale, radish and red cabbage. Sunflower is a seed. Pea is a legume. Alliums include onion. If unsure, ask a grown up.

sections.title: Tidying up
sections.text: Compost used coir if you can. Wash the coconut shells and scissors with warm soapy water. Dry well before storing for next time.

sections.title: Bee friendly paper
sections.text: Moisten the bee paper and lay it on a shallow bed of coir or potting soil. Keep it damp and in bright light. Some seeds may sprout indoors. Most will bloom outdoors in spring.

sections.title: Planting bee paper outdoors
sections.text: If it is autumn or winter, plant the paper in a pot or a patch and let the seeds sleep through winter. They will wake in spring. In colder spells, keep it dry and plant in spring.

sections.title: Explorer Quest and certificate
sections.text: Complete simple tasks. Label your shells. Take a photo on day 3, day 7 and harvest day. Try microgreens on a new food. Tick each step and collect your certificate.

sections.title: My seeds did not sprout
sections.text: Check dates. Keep the coir evenly damp. Make sure seeds are pressed to the surface and had two to three days in the dark stage. Try a warmer spot away from cold draughts.

sections.title: Windowsill too hot or cold
sections.text: Microgreens like steady warmth and light. Avoid radiators and cold draughts. Bright indirect light works best. Rotate the shells daily for even growth.

sections.title: Glossary
sections.text: Coco coir is soft fibre from coconuts used as a growing medium. Dark stage is the first two to three days covered so roots anchor. True leaves are the next set of leaves after the seed leaves.

troubleshooting.name: Leggy shoots
troubleshooting.signs: tall and bendy with tiny leaves
troubleshooting.fix: give more light and rotate daily

troubleshooting.name: Mould risk
troubleshooting.signs: fuzzy layer across the surface with a musty smell

troubleshooting.name: Dry tray
troubleshooting.fix: mist more often in warm rooms

faqs.q: Do I need a spray bottle
faqs.a: A fine mist makes watering gentle. If you do not have one, drip water slowly from a spoon.
